M.G.L. c. 209C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under the Massachusetts Probate and Family Court statutes and the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act, M.G.L. c. 209C.

M.G.L. c. 209, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\.proposition: The best interests of the child is the controlling standard for custody and visitation modifications.

Custody of a Minor, 400 Mass. 150 (1987).proposition: A party seeking modification must show that a material change in circumstances has occurred since the entry of the prior order and that modification is in the childs best interests.
Custody of a Minor, 400 Mass. 150 (1987).support_reasoning: The provided opinion is Commonwealth v. Greene, a criminal case about jury-waiver and the District Court two-tier system; it does not concern custody, modification of custody orders, or standards for modifying prior orders based on a material change in circumstances and the child’s best interests. The proposition relates to family law modification standards and is misattributed here. Therefore, this case does not support the claimed proposition.
Custody of a Minor, 400 Mass. 150 (1987).relevant_excerpt: The present two-tier de novo system in this Commonwealth grants to certain criminal defendants a choice of obtaining a jury trial in the first instance or having the case heard first in the bench session of the District Court, subject to the right of appeal to the jury session. Distinct advantages inure to a defendant making use of the two-tier system. See Lydon v. Commonwealth, supra at 365.

Matter of Custody of a Minor, 32 Mass. A.raw_text: Matter of Custody of a Minor, 32 Mass. App. Ct. 283 (1992)
Matter of Custody of a Minor, 32 Mass. A.proposition: A party seeking modification must show that a material change in circumstances has occurred since the entry of the prior order and that modification is in the childs best interests.
Matter of Custody of a Minor, 32 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a criminal appeal from convictions for indecent assault and rape, focused on evidentiary issues (other bad acts, fresh complaint, medical evidence) in a criminal trial. It does not concern custody, modification of prior custody orders, or standards for modification such as material change in circumstances or best interests of the child. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed family-law modification proposition and appears to be a miscited or incorrect case reference.
Matter of Custody of a Minor, 32 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion in the provided text of custody, modification of custody orders, material change in circumstances, or the child’s best interests. The case instead addresses: “evidence of uncharged bad acts by the defendant and of fresh complaint by the two victims… [and] the principles of law controlling on all these issues are established. Applying these principles to the facts of this case, we affirm the convictions.”

M.G.L. c. 119, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\.proposition: Where there is evidence that a child may be at risk of harm while in the care of a parent, the Court may issue temporary or emergency relief, including supervised visitation or suspension of overnights, pending a full hearing.

M.G.L. c. 209, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\.proposition: Where there is evidence that a child may be at risk of harm while in the care of a parent, the Court may issue temporary or emergency relief, including supervised visitation or suspension of overnights, pending a full hearing.

Custody of a Minor, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 19.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal forfeiture/return-of-property decision interpreting G.L. c. 276, § 3 and the meaning of “public interest” in that context. It does not address custody modification, jurisdiction, or child protection statutes or case law in Massachusetts. Therefore it does not provide authority for the broad family-law proposition described by the petitioner.
Custody of a Minor, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 19.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 276, § 3, as amended by St. 1964, c. 557, § 4, states, in pertinent part: “If an officer in the execution of a search warrant finds property or articles therein described, he shall seize and safely keep them, under the direction of the court or justice, so long as necessary to permit them to be produced or used as evidence in any trial. As soon as may be, thereafter, all property seized under clause First of section one shall be restored to the owners thereof; and all other property seized in execution of a search warrant shall be disposed of as the court or justice orders and may be forfeited and either sold or destroyed, as the public interest requires, in the discretion of the court or justice ...”

Chernin v. Chernin, 401 Mass. 574 (1988).proposition: Petitioner relies on the statutes and case law governing custody modification, jurisdiction, and child protection in Massachusetts, including but not limited to:
Chernin v. Chernin, 401 Mass. 574 (1988).case_name: New York & Massachusetts Motor Service, Inc. v. Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination
Chernin v. Chernin, 401 Mass. 574 (1988).support_reasoning: The cited opinion is not Chernin v. Chernin and does not address custody modification, jurisdiction, or child protection law in Massachusetts. It is an employment discrimination case involving religious accommodation under G.L. c. 151B and MCAD procedures. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the statutes or case law governing custody or related family-law issues in Massachusetts, and using it for that proposition would be inaccurate.
Chernin v. Chernin, 401 Mass. 574 (1988).relevant_excerpt: "New York and Massachusetts Motor Service, Inc. (New York-Mass), appeals from a judgment of the Superior Court affirming a determination of the Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination (commission) that New York-Mass discriminated against the complainant, James A. Mislak, on the basis of his religion, and awarding Mislak lost wages and interest."

W. v. W., 394 Mass. 76 (1985).proposition: Petitioner relies on the statutes and case law governing custody modification, jurisdiction, and child protection in Massachusetts, including but not limited to:
W. v. W., 394 Mass. 76 (1985).case_name: Town of Northbridge v. Town of Natick Department of Social Services
W. v. W., 394 Mass. 76 (1985).support_reasoning: The opinion is about allocation of financial responsibility for special education services between municipalities and a state agency when a child is in DSS custody, not about custody modification, jurisdiction, or child protection standards generally. While it interprets G.L. c. 119 §§ 21 and 23(A) regarding DSS custody, it does so in the narrow context of fiscal responsibility, not the broader custody-modification or child-protection framework that the proposition suggests. Thus it does not meaningfully support a citation for general custody modification, jurisdiction, or child protection law in Massachusetts.
W. v. W., 394 Mass. 76 (1985).relevant_excerpt: “The agency with custody does have the power ‘to determine the child’s place of abode, medical care and education.’ G. L. c. 119, § 21… However, an acceptance of a child into DSS custody ‘shall entail no abrogation of parental rights or responsibilities [rather, it is] a temporary delegation of certain rights and responsibilities… terminable by either.’ G. L. c. 119, § 23(A)… The DSS, therefore, is not a parent for purposes of par. 202.1(d).”

A.L. v. M.L., 452 Mass. 151 (2008).proposition: Petitioner relies on the statutes and case law governing custody modification, jurisdiction, and child protection in Massachusetts, including but not limited to:
A.L. v. M.L., 452 Mass. 151 (2008).support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not A.L. v. M.L., 452 Mass. 151 (2008), and in any event the text concerns criminal drug convictions, sufficiency of evidence, and inconsistent verdicts, not custody modification, jurisdiction, or child protection in Massachusetts. It does not discuss family law standards, relevant statutes, or jurisdictional principles applicable to custody matters. Therefore it cannot be relied on as authority for the proposition stated.
A.L. v. M.L., 452 Mass. 151 (2008).relevant_excerpt: Background. The judge could have found the following facts. In the summer of 2004 the Holyoke police department began investigating suspected drug dealing at 101 Beech Street, a ten-unit residential apartment building in Holyoke next to a public park... [The opinion proceeds to address constructive possession, joint venture liability, and inconsistent verdicts in a criminal drug case, not custody or child protection issues].

Matter of Adoption of a Minor, 420 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns interpretation of G.L. c. 272, § 53 (lewd, wanton, and lascivious persons in speech or behavior) in a criminal prosecution, focusing on elements of the offense and constitutional constraints. It does not address custody modification, jurisdiction over custody matters, or child protection statutes or procedures in Massachusetts. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition regarding custody and child protection law.
Matter of Adoption of a Minor, 420 Mass..relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 272, § 53, provides criminal penalties for “lewd, wanton and lascivious persons in speech or behavior.” … In Commonwealth v. Sefranka, 382 Mass. 108, 117-118 (1980), in order to avoid constitutional problems, we construed this language “to prohibit only the commission of conduct in a public place, or the public solicitation of conduct to be performed in a public place, when the conduct committed or solicited involves the touching of the genitals, buttocks, or female breasts, for purposes of sexual arousal, gratification, or offense….”

MacLeod v. MacLeod, 437 Mass. 402 (2002).proposition: Petitioner relies on the statutes and case law governing custody modification, jurisdiction, and child protection in Massachusetts, including but not limited to:
MacLeod v. MacLeod, 437 Mass. 402 (2002).case_name: Gutierrez v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
MacLeod v. MacLeod, 437 Mass. 402 (2002).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts statutes and case law on custody modification, jurisdiction, and child protection. MacLeod v. MacLeod is a tort and civil rights case arising from arrests by MBTA police; it deals with excessive force, qualified immunity, malicious prosecution, abuse of process, false arrest, emotional distress, and related issues. It does not address child custody, modification standards, jurisdiction under custody statutes, or child protection law, so it does not support the cited proposition.
MacLeod v. MacLeod, 437 Mass. 402 (2002).relevant_excerpt: We affirm the judgment below on the plaintiffs’ claims for malicious prosecution, civil rights conspiracy, and civil rights claims based on a lack of probable cause to arrest. We vacate the judgment with respect to the plaintiffs’ abuse of process claims, false arrest claims, and Daniella’s Federal civil rights claim based on excessive force. The case is remanded to the Superior Court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

It does not address family law, custody, jurisdiction over custody matters, or child protection, so it cannot be valid authority for the proposition stated.
L. v. M., 67 Mass. App. Ct. 483 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In this action, Scott seeks damages and reimbursement for his response costs from the defendants, pursuant to G. L. c. 21E, the Massachusetts Oil & Hazardous Material Release Prevention Act (Act), based on their prior connections to the gas company that operated the offending facility… Scott filed his complaint… alleging that the defendants were liable, pursuant to G. L. c. 21E, § 5, for the spread of hazardous materials to his property…”
